images.title: Wrentham St Nicholas' church by Adrian S Pye, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wrentham St Nicholas' church. The parish church of Wrentham, dedicated to Saint Nicholas, is located approximately 1 mile (1.6 km) to the west of the village center. This historical church boasts a mix of architectural elements from different periods. The tower, porch, and south aisle of the church date back to the 15th century, representing a notable example of medieval architecture. In contrast, the north aisle is a Victorian addition. The chancel, believed to be the oldest part of the church, likely dates back to the 13th century. It is characterized by its distinctive red-brick flying buttresses, which support the structure.

images.title: St.Nicholas Church, Wrentham by Geographer, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Both the nave and chancel of the church are remarkably spacious. The south aisle features wooden posts along the south wall, providing support for the roof beams. Inside the north aisle, there is a medieval stained glass window that depicts St. Nicholas, believed to be one of the oldest surviving pictures in England.

images.title: Five Bells Inn at Wrentham by Adrian S Pye, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Five Bells Inn at Wrentham

description: This East Suffolk village is located just 2 miles from the coast. From the village there's some nice countryside footpaths leading to the nearby woodland and beaches. The village is also notable for its ancient church which has features dating from the 13th century. This circular walk from the village uses a section of the Suffolk Coast Path to visit the beach and the pretty Benacre Broad where there's a nature reserve with lots of wildlife to see. To continue your walking around Wrentham try the Kessingland to Southwold Walk and enjoy more fine coastal paths. Please scroll down for the full list of walks near and around Wrentham. The detailed maps below also show a range of footpaths, bridleways and cycle paths in the area.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Five Bells is a charming countryside pub conveniently situated near the village. The pub is renowned for its character, featuring open fires and traditional wooden beams, creating a cosy and inviting atmosphere. It's a perfect spot to savor the best of Suffolk's local beers and indulge in delectable home-cooked dishes crafted from locally sourced ingredients. Additionally, The Five Bells offers a spacious pub garden with ample benches, providing a pleasant outdoor setting for patrons. Families will find it particularly welcoming, as there is plenty of space for children to play. You can find them at Southwold Rd, NR34 7JF. The pub is dog friendly.

display_address: Mill Lane, Wrentham, East Suffolk, Suffolk, England, NR34 7JQ, United Kingdom
